text.content:
Register your interest now for the NGI Policy Summit 2020, hosted by the City of Amsterdam and the European Commission’s Next Generation Internet (NGI) initiative.


28 - 29 September - Main conference
30 September - Fringe Day


Online and at Het Sieraad, Amsterdam

Free of charge

From 28 to 30 September, the NGI Policy Summit will bring together Europe’s leading policymakers and changemakers to set out an ambitious European vision for the future internet and explore the policy interventions and technical solutions that can help get us there. The Summit is aimed at local, national and international policymakers but we also welcome researchers, innovators and civil society organisations who can share practical ideas for a more human-centric internet. Register your interest now to join us online or live in Amsterdam.

We are closely following official guidance on the public health situation and encourage our prospective attendees to do the same before making travel arrangements. The Summit is designed as an innovative hybrid online event, meaning that you can join us either in-person or remotely - we will ask you to confirm your status a few weeks ahead of time.

The NGI Policy Summit is organised by Nesta and the City of Amsterdam, in collaboration with the European Commission. It forms part of the Next Generation Internet (NGI) programme, the Commission's flagship initiative to build a more democratic inclusive and resilient future internet. You can learn more about the NGI here and follow our policy and strategy work at the NGI Policy Lab.

profiles.name: Axel Voss MEP
profiles.excerpt: Axel is MEP for the Rhineland, Germany. A member of the EPP group, he currently sits on the JURI committee.

profiles.name: Rasmus Kleis Nielsen
profiles.excerpt: Rasmus is Director of the Reuters Institute for the Study of Journalism and Professor of Political Communication at Oxford.

profiles.name: Ingrid Schneider
profiles.excerpt: Ingrid is Professor of Political Science in the Center for Ethics in Information Technology at the University of Hamburg.

profiles.name: Marleen Stikker
profiles.excerpt: Marleen is the founder of Waag. An internet pioneer, she also founded De Digitale Stad (The Digital City) in 1993.

profiles.name: Silva Arapi
profiles.excerpt: Silva is a long-standing Digital Rights Advocate and serves as a Board Bember at Open Labs Albania.

profiles.name: Peter Bihr
profiles.excerpt: Peter is founder and MD of The Waving Cat. He explores how emerging technologies can have a positive social impact.

profiles.name: Martin Brynskov
profiles.excerpt: Martin is Associate Professor in Interaction Technologies at Aahurs University and Chair of Open &; Agile Smart Cities.

profiles.name: Ben Cerveny
profiles.excerpt: Ben is President of the Foundation for Public Code.

profiles.name: Sylvie Delacroix
profiles.excerpt: Sylvie is Professor of Law and Ethics at the Birmingham Law School, with a particular interest in Machine Ethics.

profiles.name: Marco Zappalorto
profiles.excerpt: Marco is the Chief Executive of Nesta Italia and Director of the Social Innovation Design BA at IAAD University.

profiles.name: Harry Armstrong
profiles.excerpt: Harry is Head of Technology Futures at the innovation foundation Nesta.

profiles.name: Rob	van Kranenburg
profiles.excerpt: Rob is founder of the Internet of Things Council, a hub for the practice and implementation for IoT related technologies.

profiles.name: Olivier Bringer
profiles.excerpt: Olivier is Head of the NGI Unit at DG Connect, European Commission.

profiles.name: Bas van Abel
profiles.excerpt: Bas is the founder and former CEO of Fairphone. He also co-founded De Clique.

profiles.name: Niels ten Oever
profiles.excerpt: Niels is PhD candidate with the DATACTIVE Research Group in Amsterdam, focusing Internet infrastructure and governance.

profiles.name: Suzanne Dumouchel
profiles.excerpt: Suzanne is a Research Engineer at Huma-Num, CNRS. She coordinates the TRIPLE project and is deeply involved in Open Science.

profiles.name: Geert-Jan Bogaerts
profiles.excerpt: Chariman of PublicSpaces and Head of Digital Media at VPRO

profiles.name: Katja Bego
profiles.excerpt: Katja is Project Lead of NGI Forward and Principal Researcher at innovation foundation Nesta.

profiles.name: Touria Meliani
profiles.excerpt: Touria is Deputy Mayor for Arts and Culture, Heritage and Digital Affairs at the City of Amsterdam.

profiles.name: Anna-Sophie Harling
profiles.excerpt: Anna-Sophie Harling is Managing Director for Europe at NewsGuard, based in London and New York.

profiles.name: Jack Hardinges
profiles.excerpt: Jack is Programme Lead for Data Institutions at the Open Data Institute, where he explores different approaches to data stewardship.

profiles.name: Pearse O'Donohue
profiles.excerpt: Pearse O’Donohue is Director for the Future Networks Directorate of DG CONNECT, European Commission.

text.content: The NGI Policy Summit will explore visions for the future internet, as well as ways to empower policymakers and strengthen innovation ecosystems across five topics:

sections.title: Join the discussion
sections.content:
What does it mean to build the Next Generation Internet? How should it be governed? What is Europe missing? Join the conversation ahead of the Summit and get to know the other participants on our exchange platform.

Sign up to create an account for the NGI exchange platform, hosted by Edgeryders. Registering for the platform is optional and separate from your registration for the event.

text.content: For questions or feedback, you can get in touch with us here.
